description: WXL (WiX Localization) files contain localized strings for WiX installers. They separate translatable text from the installation logic.

elements.name: WixLocalization
elements.description: Root element of a WXL localization file.

attributes.name: Culture
attributes.description: The culture/locale this file targets (e.g., en-US, de-DE, fr-FR)

attributes.name: Codepage
attributes.description: Code page for the localized strings. Auto-detected if not specified.

attributes.name: Language
attributes.description: LCID (Locale ID) for Windows Installer language. Auto-detected from Culture if not specified.

attributes.name: xmlns
attributes.description: XML namespace for WiX v4 localization

elements.name: String
elements.description: Defines a localized string that can be referenced in WiX source files using !(loc.Id) syntax.

attributes.name: Id
attributes.description: Unique identifier for referencing this string

attributes.name: Value
attributes.description: The localized string value. Can also be specified as element content.

attributes.name: Overridable
attributes.description: If yes, allows this string to be overridden by another WXL file

elements.content: The localized string text (alternative to Value attribute)

elements.name: UI
elements.description: Container for UI-specific localization (dialog control text).

attributes.name: Dialog
attributes.description: The dialog containing the control to localize

attributes.name: Text
attributes.description: The localized text for the control

localization_patterns.name: Reference in WXS
localization_patterns.description: Reference a localized string from a WXL file

localization_patterns.name: Literal with Localization
localization_patterns.description: Combine localized strings with property references

localization_patterns.name: Default with Override
localization_patterns.description: Define overridable default that can be replaced

examples.name: Basic WXL file
examples.content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<WixLocalization xmlns="http://wixtoolset.org/schemas/v4/wxl" Culture="en-US">
  <String Id="ProductName">My Application</String>
  <String Id="ProductDescription">A powerful application for productivity.</String>
  <String Id="LaunchAppText">Launch [ProductName]</String>
  <String Id="InstallDirTitle">Installation Folder</String>
</WixLocalization>

examples.name: German localization
examples.content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<WixLocalization xmlns="http://wixtoolset.org/schemas/v4/wxl" Culture="de-DE">
  <String Id="ProductName">Meine Anwendung</String>
  <String Id="ProductDescription">Eine leistungsstarke Anwendung fur Produktivitat.</String>
  <String Id="LaunchAppText">[ProductName] starten</String>
  <String Id="InstallDirTitle">Installationsordner</String>
</WixLocalization>

examples.name: Using localization in WXS
examples.content:
<Package Name="!(loc.ProductName)" Version="1.0.0" Manufacturer="!(loc.Manufacturer)" />

<!-- Reference WXL in build: wix build -culture en-US -loc en-US.wxl Product.wxs -->

best_practices: Use descriptive String IDs that indicate purpose (ProductName, WelcomeMessage, ErrorText)
Keep strings in WXL even for single-language products for maintainability
Test with longest expected translations to catch UI overflow issues
Use Overridable="yes" for strings that might need customization
Include placeholders like [ProductName] for dynamic content
Keep one WXL file per culture, named consistently (en-US.wxl, de-DE.wxl)
Document placeholders and formatting requirements in comments
Test RTL (right-to-left) languages if supporting Arabic or Hebrew

build_commands.command: wix build -culture en-US -loc en-US.wxl Product.wxs -o Product.msi
wix build -culture en-US -loc en-US.wxl -culture de-DE -loc de-DE.wxl Product.wxs
wix build Product.wxs && wix msi transform Product.msi Product_de.msi -o de-DE.mst
